IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 13755 S0926-860X(12)00405-X 10.1016/j.apcata.2012.06.041 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 TPR profiles of catalysts supported on alumina (a) and zirconia (b). Fig. 2 HRTEM images of the Z-NiPt(s) (sections (a) and (b)) and Z-NiPt(c) (sections (c) and (d)) bimetallic samples. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of bimetallic catalysts supported on zirconia. Fig. 4 Temperature programmed reaction (CH4 +CO2 →2CO+2H2) of monometallic samples. Fig. 5 HRTEM images of the Z-Pt monometallic sample. Fig. 6 MS signal (m/e =16) of the effluent gases of temperature programmed decomposition (CH4 →C+2H2) for monometallic Ni samples and following TPO profiles (m/e =44). Fig. 7 MS signal (m/e =28) of the effluent gases of temperature programmed decomposition (2CO→C+CO2) for monometallic Ni samples and following TPO profiles (m/e =44). Fig. 8 Mass spectrometry signals of the effluent gases of temperature programmed reaction (CH4 +CO2 →2CO+2H2) for bimetallic samples supported on zirconia. Fig. 9 TPO profiles (m/e =44) after 16h of time on stream (CH4 +CO2) at 1073K for zirconia supported mono and bimetallic catalysts. Table 1 Characterization of the catalysts. %Ni %Pd or %Pt Mean metal particle size Z-Ni 3.6 – 5nm Z-Pd – 0.4 17nm Z-Pt – 0.3 2nm Z-NiPd(c) 3.8 0.4 Z-NiPd(s) 3.9 0.4 Z-NiPt(c) 3.3 0.3 Z-NiPt(s) 3.4 0.3 A-Ni 5.3 – 3nm A-Pd – 0.6 14nm A-Pt – 0.3 2nm A-NiPd(c) 5.5 0.6 A-NiPd(s) 5.4 0.6 A-NiPt(c) 5.5 0.3 A-NiPt(s) 5.5 0.3 Optimization of bimetallic dry reforming catalysts by temperature programmed reaction F. Highlights ► A simple temperature-programmed procedure was used. ► Both CH4/CO2 reforming and coke formation via CH4 or CO decomposition were studied. ► Bimetallic Pd(or Pt)-Ni catalysts on zirconia and alumina were investigated. ► The co-impregnated Ni-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst looks the most promising for an industrial application. Catalytic reforming of CH4 with CO2 was investigated on mono and bimetallic Pd(or Pt)-Ni based samples supported on Al2O3 and ZrO2. A simple temperature-programmed procedure was used to study both reforming and coke formation via CH4 or CO decomposition. Catalysts supported on zirconia are more active than alumina-supported samples. The addition of Pt or Pd to Ni/ZrO2, preferably by co-impregnation, prevents coke formation. The co-impregnated Ni-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst looks the most promising for a possible industrial application. Keywords Dry reforming CO2 reforming Ni-Pt Ni-Pd Temperature programmed reaction Zirconia 1 Introduction The catalytic reforming of CH4 with CO2, rather than steam, for the production of synthesis gas (CO+H2) has attracted a considerable interest in the past 20 years for both environmental and commercial reasons. In fact it reduces CO2 and CH4 emissions, which are greenhouse gases, and it yields, in the product gas, a lower H2/CO ratio (H2:CO:1:1 or less) compared to steam reforming (H2:CO:3:1). This synthesis gas with a high CO concentration is a suitable feed for Fischer–Tropsch plants and for the synthesis of acetic acid, dimethyl ether and oxoalcohols [1]. An additional advantage of dry reforming is in those cases in which the reactants are simultaneously available at low cost, or even at negative prices [2]. The major problem preventing commercialization of the CO2 reforming is finding a suitable catalyst that will not deactivate under the conditions needed for this reaction. In fact, due to the endothermic nature of the process, high temperatures (∼1100K) are required to reach high conversions. Besides this process works in presence of high concentrations of carbon-containing compounds. These conditions lead to quick deactivation of the catalyst due to carbon deposition, which originates mainly from two reactions, i.e., methane decomposition (CH4 →C+2H2) and carbon monoxide disproportionation (2CO→C+CO2). Although in literature the authors agree that carbon formation is the primary reason for the catalyst deactivation, disagreement exists on the source of the carbon. In fact, in principle, all three carbon-containing species present in the reforming reaction (CH4, CO and CO2) can contribute to carbon deposition. Some authors [3,4] reported that CH4 decomposition is the main source of carbon, others showed that carbon originates mainly from CO [5,6]. To solve the problem of coking the following points were investigated: (i) the increase of the H/C content of the feed through the addition of water (coupling with steam reforming); (ii) the increase of the O/C content of the feed through the addition of oxygen (coupling with partial oxidation); (iii) the use of a catalyst which minimize the rate of coking. Typically, supported Ni or noble metals are reported as potential catalysts for the CH4/CO2 reforming. It has been shown [7] that Pt-based catalysts have high activity in the dry reforming reaction and are less sensitive to carbon deposition compared to Ni-based catalysts, but the latter is the metal most widely studied because of its high activity and low price, pointing to possible industrial application. The addition of alkali or alkali earth dopants to nickel [8,9], or the use of supports with basic characteristics [10,11] were reported as methods to minimize carbon deposition. Some authors [12–20] have investigated the effects of bimetallic samples in the dry reforming of methane. A very recent review has summarized some examples of the catalysts for methane steam reforming and the additive effect of noble metals [21]. With regard to dry reforming, Ni-Ru and Ni-Pd on different supports [12,17,19,20], Ni-Cu/Al2O3 [15], Ni-Rh on alumina [13,16], on silica [14], on zirconia [18], have shown to enhance the catalytic performances of the monometallic Ni sample. Bimetallic Ni-Pt samples on nanofibrous alumina [22,23] and ZSM5 [24] have been lately investigated. In the present work we have studied the promotion of Ni by a small amount of platinum or palladium in order to improve the stability of Ni-based samples. Ni-Pt or Ni-Pd bimetallic catalysts were supported on both alumina and zirconia, which are the most used and suitable supports for these catalysts. We have investigated the complex system of reactions by temperature programmed (TP) tests in order to shorten the experimental work, as required by the industry. So, a simple TP procedure was developed for both reforming and coking reactions after temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts. In particular, with the aim of studying carbon deposition, all catalysts were tested in coking reaction either via CH4 or CO temperature programmed decomposition (TPD). Then temperature programmed oxidations (TPO) were performed in order to characterize the reactivity of the coke. The set of TPR–TP–TPD–TPO provides an easy and fast way to obtain helpful information on both catalytic activity and reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zirconia support (Z) was prepared by precipitation from ZrOCl2·8H2O (Fluka) at constant pH (pH 10), aged under reflux conditions [25,26], washed free from chloride (AgNO3 test), dried at 383K overnight and finally calcined at 773K in flowing air (30mL/min STP). Al2O3 (Alu D-Akzo) was used as received (A). Supports were impregnated by incipient wetness with Ni(NO3)26H2O or H2PtCl6 or H2PdCl4 aqueous solutions to give a nominal 5wt% Ni or 0.5wt% Pt (or Pd) loaded catalyst. Bimetallic 5wt% Ni–0.5wt% Pt (or Pd) were prepared either by co-impregnation [samples denoted with (c)] or by successive impregnation [samples denoted with (s)] of metals aqueous solutions. After drying at 383K, samples were finally calcined at 773K in flowing air (30mL/min STP) for 1h. 2.2 Methods Actual metal loading was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy after microwave disgregation of the samples (50mg). TPR experiments were carried out in a home-made equipment: samples (100mg) were heated at 10K/min from 298K to 1073K in a 5% H2/Ar reducing mixture (40mL/min STP). X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded in air at 295K, with a step size of 0.05° in a 2θ scattering angle. A Philips X’Pert system was used, equipped with a focusing graphite monochromator on the diffracted beam and a proportional counter with electronic pulse height discrimination. Moreover, a divergence slit of 0.5°, a receiving slit of 0.2mm, an antiscatter slit of 0.5°, and Ni-filtered Cu KR radiation (30mA, 40kV) were employed. Prior to measurements, samples were subjected to a pre-treatment involving exposure to H2 flow for 1h at 1073K and to 1% O2/He at 298K for 15min. The particle mean size have been calculated by means of the Scherrer formula. CO and O2 chemisorption measurements were carried out at 298K using a home-made pulse flow system. Prior to measurements, samples (100mg) were subjected to a pre-treatment involving exposure to H2 flow for 1h at 1073K, followed by He purge for 2h at the same temperature. Calculations for determining the average Pd (Pt) particle size were performed using the experimental value of chemisorptions stoichiometry Pd(Pt)/CO=2, surface atomic density of 1.27×1019 atoms/m2 (Pd) or 1.25×1019 atoms/m2(Pt) and metal density of 12.02×106 g/m3 (Pd) or 21.45×106 g/m3 (Pt) respectively. With regard to O2 chemisorption on Ni samples, a stoichiometry Ni/O2 =2, a surface atomic density of 1.54×1019 atoms/m2 and a metal density of 8.9×106 g/m3 were used. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy HRTEM analyses were carried out with JEM 3010 (JEOL) electron microscope operating at 300kV, point to point resolution at Scherzer defocus of 0.17nm. Specimens for TEM analyses were sonicated in iso-propanol and then transferred as a suspension to a copper grid covered with a holey carbon film. The specimens investigated were pre-treated in H2 flow for 1h at 1073K and then in 1% O2/He flow at 398K for 15min. The temperature-programmed (TP) reactions were performed in a lab-made equipment. Before catalytic tests each sample (100mg) was reduced in H2 at 1073K in a quartz reactor, purged in He and cooled. Then all reactions were tested in the temperature range 373–1073K at 10K/min, the effluent gases being analyzed by mass spectrometry and TCD. Reforming reaction were carried out with a total flow of 40mL/min STP of 5% CH4 and 5% CO2 diluted in helium. After reaching the final temperature (1073K), the reactions were conducted for 16h of time on stream. Coking reaction, either via CH4 or CO temperature-programmed decomposition, were carried out with 5% CH4/He or 5% CO/He flow (40mL/min STP). After reforming and coking reactions, samples were cooled to ambient temperature and TPO experiments were carried out in the same equipment: samples were heated at 10K/min from 273K to 1073K in a 5% O2/He oxidative mixture (40mL/min STP). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Table 1 reports the metal loadings of the catalysts investigated, together with the mean metal particle sizes calculated by chemisorptions analyses. After metal deposition and calcination, a TPR analysis was performed to investigate the metal oxidation state and in the case of bimetallic samples to identify possible interactions between platinum (palladium) and nickel. Fig. 1(a) shows the TPR analyses of alumina supported samples. The TPR profile (not shown) of alumina support (A) is completely flat and it does not show any peak. The 0.5wt% platinum on alumina catalyst (A-Pt) shows instead a small positive peak at about 500K, that can be related to PtO reducible at this temperature. For A-Pd an extensive interaction between Pd oxide species and alumina surface is evidenced by the reduction peak in the range 573–673K [27]. Some free PdO not reducible at ambient temperature is represented by the H2 consumption peak at about 395K. The TPR spectrum of nickel supported on alumina (A-Ni) shows the simultaneous presence of various nickel species, since it presents three reduction peaks: a very small one located at about 590K, another at 910K and the third one at 1030K. Since Ni2+ is reduced to Ni0 without going through intermediate oxides, the hydrogen consumption peaks appearing in different temperature regions are to be assigned to the reduction of different species. The lowest peak is detected quite close to that of bulk NiO and can be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO particles without interaction with the alumina support [9]. The second reduction peak can be correlated to the reduction of NiO interacting with (but not chemically bound to) the support, while the high temperature-peak can be associated with the formation of nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) [9]. This latter peak is not influenced by platinum or palladium addition, in the case of bimetallic samples. On the contrary, due to the presence of platinum or palladium, the reduction peak at 910K is slightly shifted (of about 50K) toward lower temperatures, pointing to an easier reduction due to the presence of the noble metal. In the four TPR profiles of bimetallic alumina supported catalysts, a peak related to the reduction of the noble metal appears at low temperature. The presence of two distinct peaks related to platinum (or palladium) and nickel suggests the lack of interaction or alloying between the two metals. In Fig. 1(b) TPR analyses for zirconia supported catalysts are reported. The TPR profile (not shown) of zirconia support (Z) is flat, while both the monometallic samples (Z-Pt and Z-Pd) show small positive peaks associated with metal oxide reduction, meaning that neither Pt nor Pd on zirconia are completely reducible at room temperature. Curve Z-Ni refers to the calcined monometallic nickel catalyst on zirconia, and presents a very small H2 consumption peak at about 590K, and another one located at 800K. The latter is not symmetric, but slowly increases and sharply drops down, as previously reported for Ni/ZrO2 samples [28,29]. As in the TPR of alumina supported sample, the lowest peak can be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO particles without interaction with the support, while the second reduction peak can be attributed to an interaction of NiO with zirconia. The addition of platinum or palladium, both by co-impregnation and by successive impregnation, shifts to lower temperatures the beginning of the reduction peak, pointing to an enhanced reduction in presence of the noble metal. Moreover after Pd addition, the TPR profiles become complex (wider peaks), providing evidence of different Ni species that differently interact with the support [28]. The presence of two distinct peaks related to Pt (or Pd) and Ni suggest that they exist as two separate phases. Moreover, all the reduction peaks in the TPR profiles of zirconia based catalysts appear at temperature lower than the corresponding peaks in the TPR of alumina samples. This shows an enhanced metal reducibility on the zirconia support. The structure of bimetallic catalysts has been characterized by TEM analysis. The results are summarized in Fig. 2 where the images are shown for the zirconia based samples. HRTEM measurements evidence crystalline nanoparticles of zirconia whose size ranges are centered at about 10nm for all the catalysts. Ni metal particles are very difficult to observe as they are covered by the support. Some, very small, Pt round shaped particles of about 1.5–2nm are observed in some regions of the Z-NiPt (s) and Z-NiPt(c) samples (see arrows in Fig. 2 section b and section d). No evidence for alloy formation was found in any HRTEM image. Afterwards, XRD analyses of both Ni-Pd and Ni-Pt zirconia supported catalysts were performed (Fig. 3 ). Very similar XRD patterns were obtained in the four bimetallic samples, showing only the contribution coming from the support (tetragonal zirconia) and from the Ni cubic phase (2θ =44.5 corresponding to the (111) reflection). By Scherrer equation a Ni particle size of about 5–6nm can be calculated for these samples. No alloy formation was detected in the samples. However, the fact that no alloy contribution was detected cannot exclude the formation of very small (1–3nm) particles made of Ni–Pt(Pd) alloy. In conclusion, TPR profiles, HRTEM images and XRD analyses do not show evidence for the presence of an alloy in the bimetallic catalyst. 3.2 Effect of support on monometallic samples In the present paper we have investigated the complex system of dry reforming reactions by temperature programmed tests. In these methods the flow of the reagents/products is recorded as a function of the temperature linear increase. The transient nature of a TP technique, in which temperature, surface coverage and reaction rate all vary with time, allows to provide information that are not available from steady-state experiments [30]. Fig. 4 shows the results of the catalytic activity during CH4/CO2 temperature programmed reaction for monometallic samples. Mass spectrometry signals of the reactor's effluent gases are displayed versus temperature. As it can be seen, the methane conversion is always lower than the CO2 conversion, although they are present in the feed in a 1:1 ratio. This is ascribed [31] to the simultaneous occurrence of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS): CO2 +H2 →CO+H2OΔH298K =41KJ/mol. A comparison between A-Ni and A-Pt clearly show that the latter is more active than the nickel based sample. In fact A-Pt, with only 0.5wt% of the metal, starts to produce H2 at 680K, while the A-Ni, with a Ni content of 5wt%, must exceed 930K to start to convert the reactants. Also A-Pd 0.5% catalyst behaves better than the A-Ni sample, since it starts to convert CH4/CO2 at 720K. The Z-Pd sample does not improve catalytic performances with respect Z-Ni catalyst: this is probably ascribable to its very low metal dispersion after the reduction at 1073K (Table 1). From the data reported in Fig. 4, it is noteworthy that the catalytic performance (in terms of initial activity) of monometallic samples for the reforming of methane with CO2 is strongly influenced by the support. In fact, zirconia supported samples are more active than the alumina-supported ones. This is more evident in the nickel based catalysts, since Z-Ni starts to produce H2 at 590K, about 340K earlier than A-Ni (930K). Even Pt based sample reacts earlier if supported on zirconia compared to alumina: Z-Pt starts to produce H2 at 640K, while A-Pt at 680K. For platinum supported samples various hypotheses have been proposed [31] to explain this behavior: the higher dispersion of platinum, the interaction of Pt with Zr n+ centers on the support, and the surface acidity/basicity of the support. Now, we have first of all investigated the effect of Pt dispersion: values of chemisorption after a treatment at 1073K show a very high dispersion of both A-Pt and Z-Pt catalysts. In fact, the mean Pt particle size calculated for both samples is of 2nm, as reported in Table 1. X-ray diffraction patterns were also collected for these samples. The patterns of the monometallic specimens (not reported here for the sake of brevity) show the Bragg peaks coming from the ZrO2 support but no contribution coming from the metals could be detected, not even in the samples treated at 1073K. It is well known that when the particle size is smaller than 2–3nm the XRD peaks are so broadened to disappear almost completely from the pattern. To confirm this hypothesis TEM measurements were also performed. The HRTEM images of the Z-Pt monometallic sample are reported in Fig. 5 . The catalyst showed easily detectable small roundish particles, uniform in shape and size, with an average diameter of about 2–3nm, evidencing that HRTEM data are in agreement with both XRD and chemisorption results. Therefore we can exclude that the significant difference between alumina and zirconia catalysts, in terms of initial activity for the CH4/CO2 reaction, is due to metal dispersion. It is rather due to the interaction of Pt with Zr n+ centers [31], and/or to the enhanced metal reducibility on the zirconia support, as discussed in the TPR analyses reported in Fig. 1. Methane (Fig. 6 ) and carbon monoxide (Fig. 7 ) temperature programmed decompositions followed by a TPO analysis have also been performed. Z-Ni starts to activate methane at about 580K and reaches its maximum at 810K. Then the catalyst deactivates quickly due to carbon deposition. After methane temperature programmed decomposition a TPO analysis has been done: only one peak is present centered at 780K, meaning that only one carbon species has been formed in this catalyst. A-Ni sample starts hydrogen production later, with a maximum at 980K. Therefore CH4 activation is easier on zirconia supported sample than on alumina one. This supports the idea that the overall reaction rate is mainly influenced by methane activation. CO decomposition on Z-Ni occurs in three different steps: a small peak at 490K, another small one at 570K and the biggest centered at 700K. However also in this case the TPO profile presents only one sharp peak located between 600K and 900K (maximum at about 720K). CO decomposition on A-Ni is negligible. So, temperature-programmed decomposition tests have shown the formation of coke either via CH4 or CO. The comparison of the TPO profiles (Figs. 6 and 7) suggests that CH4 decomposition is the main source of carbon for nickel–alumina supported sample. Moreover, the inactivity of Ni on alumina has been explained. 3.3 Bimetallic samples Noble metal-based catalysts are less sensitive to carbon deposition compared to Ni-based catalysts [7], but the latter is the metal most widely studied because of its high activity and low price, pointing to possible industrial application. We promoted Ni with a small amount of platinum or palladium in order to improve the stability of the catalytic system. Bimetallic catalysts have been prepared in two different ways: by co-impregnation (samples denoted by (c)) and by successive impregnation (samples denoted by (s)), using zirconia as support. First of all, we have studied CH4/CO2 reforming temperature-programmed reaction for Ni-Pt and Ni-Pd bimetallic catalysts. The TP reactions are reported in Fig. 8 . The addition of Pt by co-impregnation improves the catalytic performance of the monometallic Ni catalyst, although less than expected. On the contrary, Z-NiPt(s) catalyst behaves like the monometallic Z-Ni. As for bimetallic Ni-Pd samples, the co-impregnated one starts to produce hydrogen at about 20K before the monometallic Z-Ni, while Z-NiPd(s) behaves exactly like the monometallic sample. The most important result concerns the coke formation of the bimetallic samples. Noble metal (Pt or Pd) supported on zirconia do not form coke during 16h of CH4/CO2 reforming reaction at 1073K, as proved by the complete absence of CO2 evolution. On the contrary, as reported in Fig. 9 , TPO profile of monometallic Z-Ni sample presents two different peaks (at 600K and 760K) and a band at 810–900K, suggesting the presence of three different carbon species. The addition by co-impregnation of platinum or palladium to Z-Ni sample fully prevents coke formation during 16h of time on stream (CO2 +CH4) at 1073K. In particular, it can be seen that Z-Ni sample produces a significant amount of coke, while Z-NiPt(c) and Z-NiPd(c) do not show CO2 evolution at all. Z-NiPt(s) and Z-NiPd(s) show some coke formation, anyway improving the stability with respect to monometallic Ni catalyst. In particular, for Z-NiPd(s) catalyst the TPO bands are four (at 630K, 700K, 770K, 900K), while Z-NiPt(s) presents only a peak centered at 750K. The results obtained clearly show that the presence of the noble metal (Pt or Pd) hinders the accumulation of coke on the catalyst surface. 4 Conclusions The advantages of using a temperature programmed set of reactions, i.e. reduction, CH4/CO2 reforming, CH4 and CO decomposition, oxidation of the formed coke, were successfully proved for fast development of dry reforming catalysts. The results presented in this work point out that the support plays a decisive role on the activity of the catalyst. Zirconia supported catalysts are more active than the alumina supported ones. Temperature-programmed decomposition tests show the formation of coke on the catalysts either via CH4 or CO. The addition of Pt or Pd to Ni/ZrO2, in particular by co-impregnation, prevents coke formation with respect to the monometallic Ni sample. The bimetallic Z-NiPd (c) looks the most promising for a possible industrial application. Acknowledgement We thank Mrs. Tania Fantinel for technical assistance. References [1] M. Bradford M. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic reforming of CH4 with CO2 was investigated on mono and bimetallic Pd(or Pt)-Ni based samples supported on Al2O3 and ZrO2. A simple temperature-programmed procedure was used to study both reforming and coke formation via CH4 or CO decomposition. Catalysts supported on zirconia are more active than alumina-supported samples. The addition of Pt or Pd to Ni/ZrO2, preferably by co-impregnation, prevents coke formation. The co-impregnated Ni-Pd/ZrO2 catalyst looks the most promising for a possible industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: Optimization of bimetallic dry reforming catalysts by temperature programmed reaction
